
# MyNoteServer

A simple, self-hosted note-taking and slide-making solution with first-class support for math and hand-drawn images.

---

# Features

* Notes are stored and served as plain markdown files in a single directory with arbitrary hierarchy. Use the file palette `Ctrl-p` to fuzzy-search and switch to any file instantly.
* Typed content comes _first_, based on Markdown with _first-class support_ for math and hand-drawn images.
  * Configure custom MathJax macros as well as vscode-style snippets (see the [docs](https://github.com/cemulate/mynoteserver#my-note-server)):
  $$
  \setbuilder{a \in \qq}{\what{a} > 0} = \inflim{n} \int_a^b f(x) \; dx = \sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} g(n) 
  $$
  * All builtin LaTeX commands and user macros have automatically created snippets.
 
---

# Images

* Use the image button or `Ctrl-Space` to instantly insert a sketch. You can also paste an image from the clipboard and sketch over it. 
* Images are stored **directly in the markdown file** as `![](dataUrl)` and hidden in the editor: No managing image files or worrying about links, etc.

* This means you can copy, move, or delete images as plain text.
* SVG is also supported by pasting a raw `<svg>` tag into the document; as long as it's on one line it will be hidden just like other images. With [markdown-it-attrs](https://github.com/arve0/markdown-it-attrs) you can set the size of SVG images and achieve non-trivial interesting layout effects as seen here.
* Click on an existing "Figure" badge or use `Ctrl-Space` while the cursor is next to an existing figure to edit it.

---

# Presentations

Make [Reveal.js](https://revealjs.com) slides instead of presentations! Simply start the document with `---`. In this mode, horizontal rules (`---`) are interpreted as slide boundaries. Try adding `---` at the top of this file right now to see this document as a presentation!

### Fragmented Mode

In slide mode, toggling the "Fragmented" button will **automatically** add the reveal.js `fragment` class to all block elements in your slides, making the presentation **automatically proceed step-by-step**. When editing, the currently edited slide is always displayed.

Use the fullscreen button on the toolbar to present.
See the [docs](https://github.com/cemulate/mynoteserver#my-note-server) about customizing the reveal.js or highlight.js themes; the latter is applied for code highlighting:

```javascript
const x = new Thing(`x, y, ${ value }`); 
```

---

# Other Features

* [markdown-it-attrs](https://github.com/arve0/markdown-it-attrs) is included so you can alter output HTML arbitrarily, as done on this list item. This is especially useful for floating or arbitrarily positioning images with, e.g. `{style="position: absolute; ..."}` when making Reveal.js slides. {style="max-width: 75%"}
* [markdown-it-color](https://github.com/nkjmsss/markdown-it-color) lets you {blue}(include) {red}(colored) {orange}(text).
* The editor/app is served at `/app/` (and the api at `/api/`), but there is also a `/notes/` route that serves a static view of the notes.
  * `/notes/collection/file` gives a static server-rendered view of the file that is useful for bookmarking just to read, or printing to PDF.
  * If the file is slides, the same url will render a standalone Reveal.js fullscreen presentation; use `fragmentify` in the query string to enable fragmented mode on the presentation. In particular, you can use this page to export the presentation to PDF [per the reveal.js docs](https://revealjs.com/pdf-export/)
* Basic offline support is included (the app will load, and you can work on/edit the buffer you were editing previously).
